description:
Nao, an 8th grader, is one of the only two members of a Digital Camera Club, where she also serves as the manager. It's a mystery that she shoots nothing else but the skies and clouds. One day, she finds a cat on a rooftop where she usually shoots her camera. It's a cat that knows how to manipulate the flow of a wind. Shocked to find a strange animal, Nao loses her footing and falls off from the rooftop!

Miki is the other member of the club, and also Nao's best friend. Taiki is the teacher who taught the cat how to manipulate the flow of a wind. Ryoko is a girl who has a huge crush on Taiki. And there's Jun, who helps Nao and Miki look for a cat that can fly. Then, there's Yukio, who is the widow of Taiki's deceased brother.

On the outskirts of this big city, a town off the "Wind Handlers," has been formed - and a mysterious Wind Festival is about to begin...

(Source: Production I.G)

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Iyashikei
tags.description: Primary aim is to heal the audience through serene depictions of characters' daily lives.

tags.name: Photography
tags.description: Centers around the use of cameras to capture photos.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: School Club
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a school club scene.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Time Skip
tags.description: Features a gap in time used to advance the story.

tags.name: Motorcycles
tags.description: Prominently features the use of motorcycles.

node.description:
[Website](http://www.kenjikawai.com/index_e.html) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E5%B7%9D%E4%BA%95%E6%86%B2%E6%AC%A1)

After dropping out of a nuclear engineering program at Tokai University, Kawai Kenji began studying music at Shobi Music Academy. However, he dropped out after half a year. With a few friends, he created the band Muse, playing fusion rock and participating in music competitions. Through competing in such contests, the band members became technically competent to enter the music industry and decided to part ways.

After leaving Muse, Kawai Kenji began composing music for commercials in his home studio. While recording music for [Yuji Mitsuya](https://anilist.co/staff/95874/) he met music director Naoko Asari, who advised him to compose anime soundtracks. Some of his most famous anime soundtracks can be found in [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1288/), [Ranma ½](https://anilist.co/anime/210/), [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/), [Fate/Stay Night](https://anilist.co/anime/356/), [When They Cry](https://anilist.co/anime/934/) and more recently in [Mob Psycho 100](https://anilist.co/anime/21507/).

He has worked on several projects with the director [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/) and has written scores for all of Hideo Nakata's films. Kenji Kawai's music has received the Annie award and Hong Kong Film Award in 2005, for [Ghost in The Shell 2: Innocence](https://anilist.co/anime/468/) he was nominated for an Annie award.

Following his success as an anime music composer, he became involved in live action movies. He contributed music to horror films: Ring, Ring 2, Dark Water, Japanese-Polish science-fiction film Avalon and the Hong Kong film Seven Swords.

For the music found in Seven Swords and A Battle of Wits he was nominated for Best Original Film Score Awards at both the 25th and 26th Hong Kong Film Awards in 2006 and 2007.

(Source: AniDB)

Junji Nishimura is a male Japanese director, an episode director and storyboarder from Yobuko, Saga, Japan, though he currently resides in Karatsu, Saga. After graduating from Meiji Gakuin University in 1980, Nishimura entered into the anime studio Nishiko Production. Nishimura had his first job as an episode director for Baldios in 1980, and went on to be an episode director in other series such as Six God Combination Godmars, and Magical Princess Minky Momo in 1982. In 1984, he resigned from Nishiko and in 1985 had his director debut with Pro Golfer Saru. Since then, he has worked as the director on many anime produced by Studio Deen and later on for Seven Arcs.

Nishio graduated from Nagoya Designer Academy and started his career at Anime Spot, a subcontracting studio, after being refused in interviews with several animation studios. He debuted as an in-betweener on [Osomatsu-kun](https://anilist.co/anime/9883/) and as a key animator on [Laughing Salesman](https://anilist.co/anime/3077/).

It's on [Yu Yu Hakusho](https://anilist.co/anime/392//) that Nishio came into his own as an animator, developing weighty and realistic movements influenced by [Satoru Utsunomiya](https://anilist.co/staff/101489/). Thanks to the ability demonstrated there, he was chosen to design the characters for [Ninku](https://anilist.co/anime/912/).

After working as character designer and chief animation director on [Jin-Roh](https://anilist.co/anime/570/) he permanently joined Production I.G. where he became known, together with [Hiroyuki Okiura](https://anilist.co/staff/103502/) and [Kazuchika Kise](https://anilist.co/staff/115781/), as "The Three Gods of I.G."

[Masashi Kishimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/96879/) requested for Nishio to be the character designer of the Naruto anime.

In August 2020, he was promoted to company director of Production I.G alongside [Takayuki Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/103266/Takayuki-Gotou/), a co-founder of the studio.

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/shichiro_kobayashi/)

A former art director and a guest professor at Kobe Design University.

Kobayashi graduated from Musashino Art University and first became an elementary school art teacher. It was only later that he joined the animation industry in 1964. He started quickly making a name for himself as a background artist and consequently established his own background art studio Kobayashi Production, in 1968. During this time thick poster paint was dominating the backgrounds in anime, but Kobayashi started a new style with much thinner painting and colored pencil strokes.

He has worked as an art director on over 100 titles and is one of the most distinguished art directors in the medium. Notable works include [Gamba no Bouken](https://anilist.co/anime/5267/), [Ie Naki Ko](https://anilist.co/anime/2828/), [Takarajima](https://anilist.co/anime/2618/), [Tenshi no Tamago](https://anilist.co/anime/885/), [Utena](https://anilist.co/anime/440/), [Berserk](https://anilist.co/anime/33/) and [Nodame Cantabile](https://anilist.co/anime/1698/).

Kobayashi retired from the industry in 2010, which was followed by his studio's closedown a year later.

In a 2015 [interview](https://youtu.be/V1tiKOsCz2M), Kobayashi talked about his life and passion in painting touring his atelier and showcasing his work.

Originating from Oh! Production. Former key member at [Gainax](https://anilist.co/studio/6/).

More recently he has been working on [Trigger](https://anilist.co/studio/803/)'s productions.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/iyaiyaenn/)

She started working as animator for [Shin-Ei Douga](https://anilist.co/studio/247/ShinEi-Animation), where she later debuted as assistant episode director on [Yakyuukyou no Uta](https://anilist.co/anime/10554//) and [Ikkyuu-san](https://anilist.co/anime/4935/) before she became storyboarder and then episode director on the [Doraemon](https://anilist.co/anime/2471/Doraemon-1979/) television series. In 1982, when another former Shin-ei director, [Fukutomi Hiroshi](https://anilist.co/staff/105280/Hiroshi-Fukutomi), established [Animaru-Ya](https://anilist.co/studio/386/Animaruya) she was one of the founding members together with Sanada Yoshinobu and [Honda Toshiyuki](https://anilist.co/staff/129528/Toshiyuki--Honda). She stayed at Animaru-Ya, which is presently known as [Ekura Animaru](https://anilist.co/studio/6257/Ekura-Animal), until 2004 before leaving to work as freelancer.

(Source: aniDB)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%8B%A5%E6%9E%97%E5%92%8C%E5%BC%98)

**Kazuhiro Wakabayashi** is a Japanese sound director who was formerly affiliated with Techno Sound and Omnibus Promotion. After going freelance, he established his own sound production studio on May 7, 2004 called Fonishia. In 2013, he went freelance once again after his sound production studio disbanded.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/evo_s10) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大平晋也) | [Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=shinya_ohira)

Shinya Oohira is one of the most talented and recognized animators in the world of anime. His animation style includes using exaggerating motion, manipulating gravity and balance with use of different perspective shots, lots of rapid camera movement and unconventional angles. With his boldly distorted and vigorous drawing style, his cuts are unique and instantly recognizable.

He has worked as an animator for over thirty years. His early work in the 80's mainly consisted of action and effects cuts. He bounced around several studios, including [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), and [Pierrot](https://anilist.co/studio/1/). His early cuts include [Gall Force 2: Destruction](https://anilist.co/anime/2061/), for which he animated a laser beam with a distinctly loose and vivid sense of movement. With its smooth animation and wavy motion pattern, the cut has a lively fluidity to it that can be seen as the first step towards Oohira's current distinctive visuality. He used the same approach on his smoke effects for [Akira](https://anilist.co/anime/47/) and a flood for [Angel Cop](https://anilist.co/anime/1351/). His style truly came into fruition when he started applying this to solid objects – especially people. The earliest such case is his cut in the fourth episode in [The Hakkenden: Shin Shou](https://anilist.co/anime/12715/). The Oohira "wobble," is perhaps his most distinct trademark: the animated objects expand and compress in a wobbling manner.

Aspired to become an animator after having seen [Masahito Yamashita](https://anilist.co/staff/138566/)'s work on [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/).

Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oshii_mamoru)

An anime and live-action director, mostly known for the former, whose seminal titles include [Urusei Yatsura 2: Beautiful Dreamer](https://anilist.co/anime/1921/), [Angel's Egg](https://anilist.co/anime/885/), the first two [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1095/) films and the [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/) films, as well as the Kerberos Saga universe of which [Jin-Roh](https://anilist.co/anime/570/) is a part.

His affinity for Euro arthouse cinema, his falling out with the Christian religion, and his fascination with the unsuccessful anti-occupation, pro-communist protest movement in postwar Japan shaped his unusual sensibilities. Recurring themes and aesthetics in his works include oppressive police states, unsuccessful protest movements, dysfunctional bureaucracies, political action that results in stasis, biblical scripture, and imagery, philosophical dilemmas, characters trapped in seemingly inescapable situations, the use of dialog as descriptive "texture" rather than a plot-driver, and otherwise Euro-arthouse pacing and storyboarding. He is both polarizing to mainstream audiences, and highly revered by cinephiles and Hollywood directors; his works have influenced Hollywood films such as Dark City, The Matrix, and Avatar.

[Kenji Kamiyama](https://anilist.co/staff/100348/), an anime director also closely associated with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/), is his protégé.
**Ogisu Hirotsugu (小岐須泰世)** is a Japanese producer.
